newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: No change on S.African succession - spokesmen.
newsitem.headline: No change on S.African succession - spokesmen.

text.p: Spokesmen for President Nelson Mandela and his ruling African National Congress (ANC) on Monday poured cold water on media reports that Mandela had disavowed Thabo Mbeki as his successor.
"What he said is nothing new. He repeated what he has been saying all along, namely that he does not have the right to annoint a successor," Mandela's spokesman Joel Netshitenzhe told Reuters.
The ANC said that, if anything, Mandela had reiterated his "vote of confidence" in Mbeki.
ANC spokesman Ronnie Mamoepa said: "If anything, President Mandela reiterated his vote of confidence in deputy president Thabo Mbeki in particular."
In a wide-ranging interview with The New York Times, The Times and Sowetan, Mandela stressed that it was not up to him alone to choose the country's next leader.
He said it was a "misconception" that he had tapped Mbeki for the job, since that was the prerogative of the national executive committee of his party.
"The president has no right to chose a successor and I never did so. When the president of the ANC steps down, the National Executive Committee or congress will elect a successor," Mandela said.
"If (they) elect Mbeki, I will support that because he is a competent man who deserves that position."
Mandela, 78, again repeated his determination to step down as president in 1999 when general elections are due and make way for younger blood.

Last July he gave a clear signal he believed Mbeki was the best person to fill his shoes, saying in a television interview: "He is very talented and very popular and if the organisation elected him I would feel they had made the right decision."

Johannesburg's daily The Star newspaper on Monday carried a banner headline saying "Mandela drops Mbeki bombshell", reporting that a weekend meeting of the ANC's executive was "stunned" when Mandela told them what he had said in his newspaper interview.

Mbeki, the most prominent South African leader on the international stage after Mandela, is currently on a mission to Europe to drum up trade and investment -- his latest sortie in what is widely assumed to be a process for grooming for the presidency.
